tit.e: Junsatsushi (a circuit-riding inspector or investigating commissioner) (China)

sen.j: 巡察使（じゅんさつし）は、中国・唐代に置かれた官名である。
sen.e: Junsatsushi (patrolling inspectors or investigating commissioners who travelled around and controlled the local governors by implementing the policies of the central government) was a government official title which originated in Tang China.
sen.cmt: 「巡察使」定訳不明 *investigating commissioner* (ドイツ人研究者による訳語）"To implement the policies of the central government, investigating commissioners (anchashi 安察使) had to travel around and to control the local governors." in http://www.chinaknowledge.de/History/Tang/tang-admin.html In the Cambridge History of China (pp.205-6) http://books.google.com/books?id=SuzWL1_qek4C&pg=RA2-PA619&dq=provincial+governor,+China&lr=&as_brr=0&hl=ja&cd=7#v=onepage&q=circuit%20riding&f=false
sen.e: Junsatsushi (a circuit-riding inspector or investigating commissioner) was a government official title which originated in the Tang Dynasty of China.

sen.e: Junsatsushi (a circuit-riding inspector or investigating commissioner) was a government official title which originated in the Tang Dynasty of China.

sen.j: 後には、按察使・安撫使などと称せられた。
sen.e: The junsatsushi was later given alternative names, such as an 'azechi' (or 'anchashi' in Chinese) and an 'anbushi.'
The junsatsushi was later given alternative names, such as 'azechi' and 'anbushi.'

sen.e: The junsatsushi was later given alternative names, such as 'azechi' and 'anbushi.'

sen.j: 律令には規定のない使職（令外官）の一つであり、皇帝の命令によって、地方の監察を行い、州の刺史や県の県令などの地方官の勤務評定を上進した。
sen.e: As an imperial commissioner ('shih' in Chinese) which was unregulated by the ritsuryo codes (ryoge no kan), 'junsatsushi' was in charge of an inspection of the operation of local government under the command of the emperor himself, directly reporting to the emperor on the recommendation of the promotion or demotion of local officials, such as 'shishi' (provincial governors) and 'kenrei' (prefectural governors).

As an imperial commissioner which was unregulated by the ritsuryo codes (ryoge no kan), 'junsatsushi' was in charge of the inspection of the operations of local governments under the command of the emperor himself, directly reporting to the emperor on the performance evaluation of the local officials, such as 'shishi' (provincial governors) and 'kenrei' (prefectural governors).
sen.cmt: ('shih' in Chinese)を削除しました。（仕様指示書の”「新たな情報の追加」を避け”に従い）an→the,operation→operations,government→governments,the を挿入し、”勤務評定”の部分を修正しました。
sen.e: As an imperial commissioner which was unregulated by the ritsuryo codes (ryoge no kan), 'junsatsushi' was in charge of the inspection of the operations of local governments under the command of the emperor himself, directly reporting to the emperor on the performance evaluation of the local officials, such as 'shishi' (provincial governors) and 'kenrei' (prefectural governors).

sen.j: 任命されるのは御史が多いが、その職名や人員は定まってはいなかった。
sen.e: For the most part 'gyoshi' (imperial censors) were appointed junsatsushi, but neither its title nor its membership was fixed.

sen.j: その始まりは、早くも初唐の貞観 (唐)8年（634年）に、諸道黜陟大使（一名、観風俗使）13名が任命されたのが、それであるとされる。
sen.e: It is believed that the first junsatsushi were designated as early as in 634 in the Shoto period (in early Tang), which consisted of 13 'shodo chucchoku taishi' (literally, a travelling commissioner in charge of promoting and downgrading one's office and rank based on the presence or absence of his achievements), one of which was a 'kan fuzoku shi' (literally, an inspector to supervise local customs).

sen.j: その後、開元年間の初期（713年頃）までは、多くの例を見ることができる。
sen.e: Thereafter, many examples of junsatsushi can be seen until the early Kaigen (Kaiyuan in Chinese) period (circa 713).

sen.j: 696年の李喬の上奏文によれば、686年の諸道巡察使の科目は44件を数え、その他、格（勅令）による訪察が30余ヵ所あったという。
sen.e: Li Qiao's report to the throne which was written in 696 referred to forty-four subjects of shodo junsatushi (travelling commissioners) and thirty and more investigative visits in accordance with 'kyaku' (supplementary imperial ordinances which were augmented to revise a preceded administrative law in the statutes [Ling 令] of the ritsuryo law).
sen.cmt: 原文に「格勅令」とありますが、「格（勅令）」（リンク先の表示）と修正致しました。

sen.j: 巡察使は、3月に出発して、11月に帰還し報告をするが、その間に、千人単位の地方官を評定する必要があったので、それだけの数をこなすのはとても難しいと述べられている。
sen.e: Junsatsushi were sent out on circuit in March and returned for reporting to the emperor in November, and during that period they were required to rate thousands of local governors, which Li Qiao had thought to be quite hard.
